moves.3. Nfd2: Not the best move, actually. Eventually, I ended up trading this knight for one of his. It never did much.
moves.4... Ne7: Black moves the knight into play
moves.6. Qe2: Moving my queen out of danger
moves.6... g5: Not the smartest move. I don't know why Black did this.
moves.7. Qh5+: Putting the king in check again
moves.8. Qe2: I don't remember why I did this.
moves.9. Qh5+: Putting the king in check again
moves.11. Bd3: Moving my bishop out of danger
moves.11... f4: Black moves the pawn; I think he was trying to open up a path for some of his other pieces. Looking back, I should have done Bxg6+, to which Black would have responded hxg6, and then I could have done Qxh8 and gotten a huge advantage.
moves.12. exf4: I didn't see the move and went after the pawn instead.
moves.13. Nf3: Moving my knight farther out into play
moves.14... Qf6: Protecting the knight, pawns, and rook all at the same time.
moves.16. Qg4: Putting extra pressure on the pawn on f.
moves.16... Qxd4: I forgot to protect my pawn.
moves.18. Bxg6+: Taking the pawn and checking the king
moves.19. Bg5+: Putting the king in check again
moves.21. Nd2: Moving my other knight into play
moves.24. Bd3: Moving the bishop out of danger. Interesting thing to note: this bishop doesn't move for a dozen turns or so after this move!
moves.27... Bxc3+: He takes my pawn and checks me again
moves.28... Rg4: Moving the rook into play again.
moves.29. h4: Moving my pawn forward to try and promote it. (When I made this move, I remember thinking that the rightmost side of the board is the least congested and it has the rook to protect it, so this pawn might be able to make it all the way across.)
moves.29... c5: I think Black was thinking that the next move would be c4 and then he could get either my knight or my bishop.
moves.30... Rb4: I can't seem to figure out what the reasoning was behind this move.
moves.32... Bg4+: Putting me in check. Black would have been much better off doing Rxh4, because eventually, that pawn does become a queen.
moves.35... Rfxa2: Black takes my pawn. Battle of the rooks ensues.
moves.36. Rxb5+: Battle of the Rooks will be right back, after these messages! LOL. I take the pawn and check the king
moves.39. Rxd5+: I take the pawn and check the king again
moves.41. Nc6+: Checking the king again and aiming for the pawn
moves.41... Ka8: Moving out of check while still protecting the pawn
moves.42. Bf5: Trading bishops to open up a path for my pawn again
moves.43... a5: Probably intending to promote the pawn
moves.44. Rxa5+: I take the pawn, checking the king and deciding to trade my rook for his. Worst comes to worst, he takes my rook and I take his, and then I can concentrate on promoting that pawn.
moves.48. Ng6: Moving out of danger and protecting the pawn
moves.48... Ke6: Black is trying to salvage the game by capturing my pawn with his king
moves.49. Kd4: Moving my king to try and prevent that.
moves.50. Ne5: Moving my knight out of danger
moves.50... Kf4: Trying to get closer to the pawn
moves.51. Kd5: I move my king to try and move it close to the pawn so that I can repel the king
moves.55. h7: Black will probably take my knight, but at least I'll be able to promote my pawn.
moves.61. Qh3+: Putting the king in check again
moves.62. Qf3: Trying to mate without ending in a draw
moves.64. Qd3: Trying to avoid a stalemate and move my king closer
moves.65. Kf3: Moving the king closer to provide support to mate.
moves.67. Qg2#: Mate. I think if somehow I had been able to keep either my knight or my rook along with my queen, it wouldn't have taken so long, but still... If I were Black and only had the king left, I would have just resigned. I suppose Black was hoping I'd make a mistake and it would be a draw instead.
